origin_of_ch_char_book: East Asian people would kneel down in front of others to indicate their modesty and humility. Today, the Japanese and Korean still preserve such a custom. They usually sit on their knees in the presence of their elders. (ÊØî, bi, compare) shows two people raising their hands and bowing down on their knees simultaneously. By following others while showing a polite appearance, people compare themselves to each other. (Âåó, bei, north) means two people standing opposite to each other. One does not follow the other‚Äôs politeness. When people see the sun in the south, the opposite side is the north. So this means ‚Äònorth‚Äô. And when the flesh (ËÇâ, rou, flesh) is added to this character (ËÉå, bei, back; go against), it means ‚Äòback‚Äô, ‚Äòbetrayal‚Äô.,Offerings sacrificed for royal ancestral rites. There are multiple layers of meat on the altar. The meat sacrificed for the rites is considered very sacred. After the ceremony, the sacrificial meat is delivered to the nobles in whom the King trusts. (Êúâ, you, have) On top of the symbol is the right hand (Âèà, you, again) delivering sacrificial offerings to the others repeatedly, and the below (ËÇâ, rou, flesh) is the sacrificed meat. Because the meat belongs to the King or owners, (Êúâ, you, have) this character was used as ‚Äòto have‚Äô. The carcases of large animals like cows or sheep were cut up to fit inside the cauldron. After the ritual, the cauldron would be emptied using a round ladle. (Âì°, Âëò, yuan=y√ºan, member) shows using a round ladle to scoop up something from the bronze cauldron. After the ceremony the King shared the contents cooked in the bronze cauldron with his court. Therefore, the character Âì° (Âëò, yuan, member) came to mean people belonging to the organization, or civil servants.,The sacrifices for ceremonies were not only meat (ËÇâ, rou, flesh). Among the elements of the symbol ‚Äú‚Äù (Áçª, ÁåÆ, xian=hsien, offer, dedicate), is the head of a tiger roaring (Ëôé, hu, tiger). Why is the head of a tiger on top of the ceremonial cauldron? And what about the animal next to it which is similar to the dog? In ancient China, the head of a prisoner of war or a precious animal might also be offered to the king or the gods. One of the discoveries from ancient sites shows a human head still inside a bronze cauldron. The character shows a head of precious animals such as a tiger, and maybe even a dog was used as sacrifice.,What do you think (Ë∫´, shen, body) is? It used to mean a pregnant woman with a child inside her. Now it means ‚Äúbody‚Äù. At long last, the woman gives birth to a baby. describes a woman giving birth to a child (Â≠ê, zi=tzu, child), bleeding blood . This character has changed to (ËÇ≤, yu=y√º, give birth to, bring up), a newborn child and flesh (ËÇâ, rou, flesh), meaning that a new born child is gradually growing up. After giving birth, she breastfeeds the baby. shows a mother with her breast out to feed the baby and the baby trying to suckle. A mother embracing the child feels so happy, this character means ‚Äògood‚Äô, ‚Äòlike‚Äô. And the shape was also changed as (Â•Ω, hao, good;love).
humanum_full_description_en:
The shape of oracle bone inscriptions resembling animal flesh, evolved from oracle bones to small seals, and a stroke may be added to the " flesh ", and the shape of the character gradually mixed with the shape of the " moon ". The original meaning is the flesh of birds and beasts. "Shuowen": "Meat, subroutine. Pictogram. All flesh is derived from meat." Duan Yucai's note: "Meat, big worms, that is the meat of birds and beasts.... People call muscles, birds and beasts call meat. This is the difference." "ËÇâ" is one of the main radicals of Chinese characters.

Since the character "ËÇâ" in the Warring States period is similar to the character "Êúà", many of the characters next to "ËÇâ" are mixed with those next to "Êúà". " Meat " in the official script, regular script, in order to avoid with " month " mixed, so the fan into " meat " shape. In addition, " meat " as well as " Shishido vulgar body writing", the " meat ", " six " ancient sound similar, so the " meat " of the vulgar body to " six " is phonetic.

Oracle is used as the original meaning, referring to animal flesh. "Collection" 6507: "Almost (call) take meat." Also used as a person's name, "Collection" 21017: "Ling (mand) meat cutting."

Warring States Bamboo Slips are also used as the original meaning, referring to animal meat. "Shangbo Bamboo Book II. "Lupang Drought" Jane 6: "Gong Kai (qi) is not full of Êùí (liang) (eating) meat (zai)."
humanum_short_description_en: oracle bone inscriptions are like animal flesh, the original meaning is the flesh of birds and beasts.
